Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Exercise and Nutritional Intake Post-Oesophagectomy

Background: Post-treatment nutritional challenges are common in patients with localized oesophageal cancer. This study assesses the effects of a 12-week supervised exercise programme on energy and protein intake, body composition, and malnutrition risk.

Methods: Conducted in nine Dutch hospitals from 2015 to 2019, this multicentre randomised controlled trial involved patients post-oesophagectomy. Participants were randomly assigned to a 12-week exercise intervention or usual care. The primary outcome was quality of life, with secondary outcomes including dietary intake and body composition. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed. Blinding was not applicable.

Participants: Eligibility criteria included patients post-oesophagectomy. Of 120 participants, 79 were invited for dietetic measurements, and 37 consented.

Results: At baseline, 63.2% had adequate energy intake, and 37.6% had adequate protein intake. Post-intervention, no significant differences in energy and protein intake were observed between groups. The exercise group showed a non-significant weight reduction compared to controls (−1.19 kg, 95% CI −2.48 to 0.10). Malnutrition risk declined in the exercise group but was not significantly different from controls. The exercise group had a higher measured resting energy expenditure per kg weight (1.62 kcal/kg, 95% CI 0.42 to 2.81).

Interpretation: The exercise programme did not significantly improve dietary intake but showed a trend towards reduced malnutrition risk and increased energy expenditure. These findings highlight the need for integrated nutritional strategies during exercise programmes to enhance recovery post-oesophagectomy.

Trial registration: NTR5045.

Funding: Not specified.
